title: 1676-B
statement: B. Equal Candiestime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputThere are $$$n$$$ boxes with different quantities of candies in each of them. The $$$i$$$-th box has $$$a_i$$$ candies inside.You also have $$$n$$$ friends that you want to give the candies to, so you decided to give each friend a box of candies. But, you don't want any friends to get upset so you decided to eat some (possibly none) candies from each box so that all boxes have the same quantity of candies in them. Note that you may eat a different number of candies from different boxes and you cannot add candies to any of the boxes.What's the minimum total number of candies you have to eat to satisfy the requirements?InputThe first line contains an integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 1000$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains an integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq 50$$$) — the number of boxes you have.The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq a_i \\leq 10^7$$$) — the quantity of candies in each box.OutputFor each test case, print a single integer denoting the minimum number of candies you have to eat to satisfy the requirements.ExampleInput551 2 3 4 561000 1000 5 1000 1000 1000101 2 3 5 1 2 7 9 13 538 8 8110000000Output10 4975 38 0 0NoteFor the first test case, you can eat $$$1$$$ candy from the second box, $$$2$$$ candies from the third box, $$$3$$$ candies from the fourth box and $$$4$$$ candies from the fifth box. Now the boxes have $$$[1, 1, 1, 1, 1]$$$ candies in them and you ate $$$0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 = 10$$$ candies in total so the answer is $$$10$$$.For the second test case, the best answer is obtained by making all boxes contain $$$5$$$ candies in them, thus eating $$$995 + 995 + 0 + 995 + 995 + 995 = 4975$$$ candies in total.

You have $n$ boxes, each containing a different number of candies. You want to give each of your $n$ friends one box of candies. To make sure everyone is happy, you want all the boxes to have the same number of candies. You can eat candies from each box to achieve this, but you can't add any candies to the boxes.

What is the minimum total number of candies you need to eat?

Input:

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains the number of boxes, $n$.
    * The second line contains $n$ integers, $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$, representing the number of candies in each box.

Output:

For each test case, print the minimum number of candies you need to eat.

You have a number of boxes, each containing a different number of candies. You want to give each of your friends one box, but you want them to have the same number of candies. You can eat candies from each box to make this happen. What is the minimum total number of candies you need to eat?
